captions.text:
When I was six, I ate 
a bag of packing peanuts,

just to see 
if they would taste like peanuts.
(Laughter)
They didn't.
(Laughter)
I've always been extremely curious.

My life has revolved around
asking questions,

questions that have oftentimes driven me
to do things of dubious advisability
(Laughter)
like eating packing peanuts.

Another one of these incidences 
occurred four years ago,
during my freshman year of high school.

There was a week 
that was unusually stressful,
and I wasn't getting very much sleep.

I started to developing a skin rash 
on my hands and my elbows.

My dermatologist explained that it was 
most likely due to my lack of sleep,

but at the time, I didn't quite understand
how sleep could affect my skin.

So, being a curious self, 
I decided to run an experiment,
in my closet, with two mice.
(Laughter)

Little did I know that I managed to buy 
one male and one female mouse
(Laughter)
put them in the same cage,

and before I knew it, I had 
a lot more than just two mice.
(Laughter)

I would later discover that my skin rash
is actually a type of allergic reaction,
known as erythema multiforme

which can be caused by the same bacteria
that causes pneumonia.

Basically, all of those evenings 
with very little sleep has stressed
my body to the point

where I was extremely vulnerable
to bacterial infection.

So now I understood 
what my dermatologist was talking about,
how sleep could affect skin.

But my curiosity didn't end there, 
I still had so many questions.

Why do we need sleep?
How do we get rid of allergies?

And the one 
that was most intriguing to me:

what other factors 
affect skin development?
I wanted to explore that question further,
but rather than run

another potentially catastrophic experiment
to my closet

I decided to look for a real position
at a real research institute.

So, after emailing countless professors
at University of Colorado at Boulder,

I eventually found myself performing
graduate-level developmental research,
as a freshman in high school.
(Applause)

The lab I was working in was focused 
on a particular aspect of skin development

specifically, the development 
of skin cancers.

Skin cancer is a huge problem,
especially here in Colorado.

It's the most commonly diagnosed cancer 
in the United States.
In fact,

about one out of every five Americans 
will develop some former skin cancer
in their life time.

Here in Colorado 
where we have over 300 days of sunshine,

skin cancer affects nearly twice as many
people compared to the national average.

There are three major types 
of skin cancer: basal cell carcinoma,
squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma.

The first two, basal cell and squamous
cell carcinoma are the most common,

with about 1 million new cases 
annually in the United States.
Even though they are rarely invasive,

they still contribute to about a quarter
of all skin cancer related deaths.

The third type, melanoma 
is considerably more malignant.

In fact one American dies 
of melanoma almost every hour.
Currently, we have

many available treatments 
for these skin cancers,
except none of them are very efficient.

That's because they not only 
affect tumors,

they are also damaging 
perfectly healthy tissue,
and that's where my work comes in.

I want to find a way 
that specifically target skin cancers,
without damaging any of surrounding cells.

But cancer work is rarely 
that simple or easy

because cells are, 
quite frankly, very, very complicated.
If one of you cells was a city,

then this is what the subway map 
might look like.
A city has more than just a subway,

there are buildings,
roads, airports, buses.

This process here is only 
a portion of what the cell does,
but it's extremely important, nonetheless.

This particular map illustrates 
cellular metabolism,

the collection of all 
of chemical processes that occur in a cell
in order to maintain life.

Each of the subway stations 
represents a chemical,

and lines that connect them 
represent proteins.

I wanted to find a single protein 
out of all of these

that is only expressed in skin cancers
and not in healthy skin cells.

As you can see, that task 
was particularly daunting,
but eventually,

through a very extensive process
of trial and error,

I came across 
a potential protein candidate,
a protein known as

Malonyl CoA (Coenzyme A)-acyl 
carrier protein transacylase,
or MCAT for short.

MCAT plays a very specific role 
in the cell,
to convert one chemical into another
except of functions in a larger pathway

that is responsible for 
the cell's production of energy.

Without MCAT, 
this entire pathway falls apart,

and the cell is no longer capable 
of generating large sums of energy.
I wanted to see

what would physically happen
to these cells,
if I were to remove this MCAT.

I predicted that healthy skin cells,
because they don't use very much energy,

should be able to function 
normally without MCAT.
On the other hand, skin cancer cells,

because they grow so rapidly,
and consume so much energy,
should rely heavily on my MCAT activity.

To test this, I had to first reduce
the amount of MCAT in these cells.

Normally, a ribosome 
translates a messenger RNA

in order to produce 
the mature MCAT protein.

However, we can interfere 
with this process

by binding a short strand of RNA
to the messenger RNA.

This then, physically blocks
the ribosome

preventing it from producing 
the MCAT protein.

The results of this procedure
are absolutely phenomenal.

Here we see the growth 
of a healthy skin cell
over the span of about two weeks.

Underneath it, we see the growth 
of a skin cell with MCAT inhibited.

As you can see, there is virtually 
no difference between these two samples.

Now let's look at the results
for the cancer cells.
These are squamous cell carcinomas,

and again, we see 
a relatively consistent rate of growth.

However, when I remove MCAT 
from these cancer cells,
we see almost no growth at all.
(Applause)

Essentially, I found a protein 
that when inhibited

can prevent skin cancer growth 
without affecting skin tissue growth,
and the implications of this are huge.

In the future, we will be able 
to develop a lotion
that can deliver a drug to inhibit MCAT.

People can apply this lotion 
to a region with a potential skin tumor.

As a result, they are preventing 
the onset of skin cancer,

without affecting 
any of the surrounding tissue.

A treatment like this is not only much
more effective than current therapies,

it's also more accessible, 
less invasive, and much cheaper.
Thank you.
(Applause)

Usually, when I explain my research 
to people, they respond by saying,
"Oh, so you cure cancer!"

and while this notion 
of curing cancer sounds very grand,

the general idea is 
actually greatly misunderstood.

In reality, the word cancer itself 
is quite misleading because it encompasses

so many different types
and so many different causes.

But take a look again 
at our cell subway map.
In a healthy cell,

every single one of these components
works together as a system,
all of the trains run smoothly.

But when even a single train 
runs off its track,
the entire system loses control.
That's how it is with cancer cells.

They are simply too complex 
for us to find a generic cure.
So no, I did not cure cancer.

In fact, nobody is ever going 
to cure cancer.

But all of our discoveries and all 
of our achievements are small steps
towards a world without cancer.

Likewise, it takes 
the same small steps to uncover
the countless other mysteries in life.

And so today, I encourage all 
of you to take those small steps,

to ask questions, to experiment, 
to do things of dubious advisability
(Laughter)

because ultimately, 
it's those explorations

that help us better understand 
the complexities around us.
Thank you.
(Applause)

title: Engineering micro-RNA to cure skin cancer | Larry Zhang | TEDxMileHigh
